verses.text: Then Job answered the LORD and said:
verses.comment: Job responds to God, finally humbled and penitent after the Lord's speeches demonstrating His sovereignty and wisdom.

verses.text: "I know that you can do all things, and that no purpose of yours can be thwarted."
verses.comment: Job acknowledges God's omnipotence, realizing that nothing can oppose His will—see also Psalm 115:3.

verses.text: "You asked, 'Who is this that hides counsel without knowledge?' Therefore, I have spoken things I did not understand, things too wonderful for me, which I did not know."
verses.comment: Job quotes God's earlier challenge and repents for speaking beyond his understanding, reflecting humility before divine mystery.

verses.text: "You said, 'Hear, and I will speak; I will question you, and you will make it known to me.'"
verses.comment: Job continues to recall God's challenge for him to answer—a call that reveals the finite understanding of humans.

verses.text: "I had heard of you by the hearing of the ear, but now my eye has seen you;"
verses.comment: Job speaks of encountering God's presence firsthand, a spiritual transformation—compare the idea of seeing God to Matthew 5:8.

verses.text: "Therefore I despise myself, and repent in dust and ashes."
verses.comment: Job's contrition calls to mind the biblical theme of repentance with humility (see Colossians 3:12), which anticipates the need for sacramental confession and penance found more fully in later tradition.

verses.text: After the LORD had spoken these words to Job, the LORD said to Eliphaz the Temanite, "My anger burns against you and against your two friends, for you have not spoken of me what is right, as my servant Job has."
verses.comment: God vindicates Job's honesty, rebuking Job’s friends for presenting a distorted understanding of God's ways—an early witness against self-righteous presumption.

verses.text: "Now therefore, take seven bulls and seven rams and go to my servant Job, and offer up a burnt offering for yourselves. And my servant Job will pray for you, for I will accept his prayer, not to deal with you according to your folly. For you have not spoken of me what is right, as my servant Job has."
verses.comment: Notice the mediatory role assigned to Job for his friends’ atonement. This pattern anticipates a tradition where righteous intercession is effective for others—see James 5:16. The sacrificial element foreshadows Christ’s singular atoning sacrifice and the perpetuation of intercessory ministry.

verses.text: So Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite went and did as the LORD had told them, and the LORD accepted Job’s prayer.
verses.comment: Obedience to God's prescribed form of worship and repentance is presented as necessary for restoration—this points toward the importance of divinely instituted means for forgiveness.

verses.text: And the LORD restored Job's fortunes, when he had prayed for his friends. And the LORD gave Job twice as much as he had before.
verses.comment: Job’s restoration comes after he prays for others, showing the blessing that results from sacrificial love and intercessory prayer. This aligns with the spiritual teaching that returning good for evil is transformative.

verses.text: Then all his brothers, all his sisters, and everyone who had known him before came to him and ate bread with him in his house. And they showed him sympathy and comforted him for all the evil that the LORD had brought upon him. And each of them gave him a piece of silver and a gold ring.
verses.comment: The renewed fellowship around shared bread carries sacramental overtones, suggesting ultimate restoration through communal worship and generosity.

verses.text: And the LORD blessed the latter days of Job more than his beginning. He had fourteen thousand sheep, six thousand camels, a thousand yoke of oxen, and a thousand female donkeys.
verses.comment: Job was blessed with more than he had lost. The doubling of his possessions is symbolic of full restoration, a biblical image of God’s generosity.

verses.text: He also had seven sons and three daughters.
verses.comment: Unlike his wealth, Job’s children are not doubled, which many interpret as hinting at the ongoing existence (possibly afterlife destiny) of his previous children—an early spiritual seed for hope in resurrection.

verses.text: He called the name of the first daughter Jemimah, the name of the second Keziah, and the name of the third Keren-happuch.
verses.comment: The naming of his daughters highlights their valued place and beauty, reflecting God's equal care for all his children.

verses.text: And in all the land there were no women so beautiful as Job’s daughters. And their father gave them an inheritance among their brothers.
verses.comment: Job gives an inheritance to his daughters along with his sons, an extraordinary move in ancient society foreshadowing a deeper sense of justice and grace in God’s providence.

verses.text: After this Job lived 140 years, and saw his sons, and his grandsons, four generations.
verses.comment: The mention of long life and seeing several generations points to the biblical association of blessing with longevity and family continuity.

verses.text: And Job died, old and full of days.
verses.comment: The phrase 'full of days' emphasizes the peace and fulfillment of a righteous life, suggesting the ultimate reward for perseverance and faith—anticipating a hope in life beyond death.
